# Effects of alcohol on memory

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[Ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol "Ethanol") is the type of [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol
"Alcohol") found in [alcoholic beverages](/wiki/Alcoholic_beverages "Alcoholic
beverages"). It is a [volatile](/wiki/Volatility_\(chemistry\) "Volatility
\(chemistry\)"), [flammable](/wiki/Flammable "Flammable"),
[colorless](/wiki/Color "Color") liquid that acts as a [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system")
[depressant](/wiki/Depressant "Depressant").[1] Ethanol can impair different
types of [memory](/wiki/Memory "Memory").

structure.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Ethanol-

## Mode of
action[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Mode of action")]

### Effects on
hippocampus[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Effects on hippocampus")]

Alcohol acts as a general central nervous system depressant, but it also
affects specific areas of the brain to a greater extent than others. Memory
impairment due to alcohol has been linked to disruption of
[hippocampal](/wiki/Hippocampus "Hippocampus") function—in particular
affecting [gamma-Aminobutyric acid](/wiki/Gamma-Aminobutyric_acid "Gamma-
Aminobutyric acid") (GABA) and [N-methyl-D-aspartate](/wiki/N-methyl-D-
aspartate "N-methyl-D-aspartate") (NMDA) neurotransmission which negatively
impacts [long-term potentiation](/wiki/Long-term_potentiation "Long-term
potentiation") (LTP).[2] The molecular basis of LTP is associated with
learning and memory.[3] Particularly, damage to [hippocampal CA1
cells](/wiki/Hippocampus_anatomy "Hippocampus anatomy") adversely affects
memory formation,[4] and this disruption has been linked to dose-dependent
levels of alcohol consumption.[5] At higher doses, alcohol significantly
inhibits neuronal activity in the CA1 and CA3 [pyramidal
cell](/wiki/Pyramidal_cell "Pyramidal cell") layers of the
[hippocampus](/wiki/Hippocampus "Hippocampus").[6][7][8] This impairs memory
encoding[9] since the hippocampus plays an important role in the formation of
new memories.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Hippocampal-
pyramidal-cell.png/220px-Hippocampal-pyramidal-
cell.png)](/wiki/File:Hippocampal-pyramidal-cell.png)

[](/wiki/File:Hippocampal-pyramidal-cell.png "Enlarge")

A Hippocampal Pyramidal Cell

### Molecular effects on GABA and NMDA
receptors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Molecular effects on GABA and NMDA receptors")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/GABAA_receptor_schematic.png/220px-
GABAA_receptor_schematic.png)](/wiki/File:GABAA_receptor_schematic.png)

[](/wiki/File:GABAA_receptor_schematic.png "Enlarge")

A GABAA Receptor

[Alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol "Alcohol") acts as a positive
[allosteric](/wiki/Allosteric "Allosteric") modulator of GABA
[receptors](/wiki/Receptor_\(biochemistry\) "Receptor \(biochemistry\)"),
specifically type [GABAA](/wiki/GABAA "GABAA").[10] Upon activation, these
GABA receptors conduct [Cl-](/wiki/Cl- "Cl-"), resulting in
[neuronal](/wiki/Neuron "Neuron")
[hyperpolarization](/wiki/Hyperpolarization_\(biology\) "Hyperpolarization
\(biology\)"). This hyperpolarization decreases the chance of an [action
potential](/wiki/Action_potential "Action potential") occurring and, thus, has
an inhibitory effect on [neurotransmission](/wiki/Neurotransmission
"Neurotransmission") in the [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system"). GABAA receptor
subtypes vary in their sensitivity to dosage of alcohol consumed. Furthermore,
acute alcohol intake promotes GABAergic neurotransmission via
[presynaptic](/wiki/Chemical_synapse "Chemical synapse") release of GABA,
dephosphorylation of GABAA receptors (increasing GABA sensitivity), and
elevation of [endogenous](/wiki/Endogeny "Endogeny") GABAergic [neuroactive
steroids](/wiki/Neuroactive_steroid "Neuroactive steroid").[11] [Protein
kinase C](/wiki/Protein_kinase_C "Protein kinase C") (PKC) has been implicated
in differentially modulating the response of the GABAA receptor to alcohol,
with effects depending on the PKC [isozyme](/wiki/Isozyme "Isozyme").[12]
Alcohol effects have also implicated [protein kinase A](/wiki/Protein_kinase_A
"Protein kinase A") in affecting GABAA receptor function, such as promoting
sensitivity.[13] Enhancement of GABAergic transmission due to alcohol
consumption can also be brought about by neuroactive steroids, such as
[allopregnanolone](/wiki/Allopregnanolone "Allopregnanolone"), which act as
GABAA receptor [agonists](/wiki/Agonist "Agonist").[11][14] Chronic alcohol
consumption and alcohol dependence are correlated with altered expression,
properties, and functions of the GABAA receptor that may contribute to alcohol
tolerance.[11] There is still much to be discovered about alcohol’s specific
and varying effects on the GABAA receptor and its subtypes.

At higher doses, ethanol also affects [NMDA receptors](/wiki/NMDA_receptor
"NMDA receptor") (NMDARs) by inhibiting the [ion](/wiki/Ion "Ion") current
induced by NMDA, a [glutamate receptor](/wiki/Glutamate_receptor "Glutamate
receptor") agonist.[15] This inhibition of synaptic excitation by alcohol has
been shown to be dose-dependent (up to a certain point, after which it did not
differ by much).[16] Alcohol appears to produce this inhibition by using a
site of the NMDAR that is accessible from the
[extracellular](/wiki/Extracellular "Extracellular") environment.[17] Thusly,
this inhibition of an ion current usually produced by NMDAR activation leads
to decreased LTP in hippocampal areas.[18] Alcohol negatively affects LTP to a
greater degree in immature versus mature animals.[19] In adolescents, alcohol
decreases the expression of the NMDAR NR2A subunit in the hippocampus and the
NR1 subunit in the prefrontal cortex.[20] Studies have also found a decrease
in phosphorylation of 2B subunit in the prefrontal cortex, hippocampus,
nucleus accumbens, and striatum.[21] NMDARS may be affected by PKA regulation
due to the actions of alcohol.[22] Alcohol’s effects on GABAA
neurotransmission may indirectly inhibit the activity of the NMDAR and
contribute to its blockade of LTP induction; however, alcohol’s direct effects
on NMDAR alone are sufficient for the inhibition of LTP.[23] The varying dose-
dependent response to alcohol relies on the combined interactions and
responses of the GABAA receptors, NMDARs, and metabotropic glutamate receptors
subtype 5 ([mGluR5](/wiki/MGluR5 "MGluR5")).[24][25][26] These changes prevent
excitatory [synaptic transmissions](/wiki/Synaptic_transmission "Synaptic
transmission") from occurring, affecting [synaptic
plasticity](/wiki/Synaptic_plasticity "Synaptic plasticity") and, in turn,
[memory](/wiki/Memory "Memory") and [learning](/wiki/Learning "Learning").
However, there is still much to be elucidated concerning specific molecular
mechanisms of how alcohol affects memory formation.

### Effects on other brain
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Effects on other brain regions")]

Alcohol also impairs and alters functioning in the
[cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum"), which affects motor function and
coordination.[27] It has a notable inhibitory effect on neurons of the
[cerebral cortex](/wiki/Cerebral_cortex "Cerebral cortex"), affecting and
altering thought processes, decreasing inhibition, and increasing the pain
threshold. It also decreases sexual performance by depressing nerve centers in
the [hypothalamus](/wiki/Hypothalamus "Hypothalamus").[28][29] Alcohol also
has an effect on urine excretion via inhibition of [anti-diuretic
hormone](/wiki/Anti-diuretic_hormone "Anti-diuretic hormone")
([ADH](/wiki/Vasopressin "Vasopressin")) secretion of the [pituitary
gland](/wiki/Pituitary_gland "Pituitary gland"). Lastly, it depresses
breathing and heart rate by inhibiting neuronal functioning of the
[medulla](/wiki/Medulla_oblongata "Medulla oblongata").[30]

## Long-term
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Long-term memory")]

**[Long-term memory](/wiki/Long-term_memory "Long-term memory")** (LTM) has a
long duration and large capacity.[31] Memories stored in LTM can last from a
few days to a lifetime.[31] LTM consists of [explicit
memory](/wiki/Explicit_memory "Explicit memory") (requiring conscious
awareness) and [implicit memory](/wiki/Implicit_memory "Implicit memory")
(unconscious awareness).[31] Information selected for LTM goes through three
processes. First, in the [encoding](/wiki/Encoding "Encoding") stage,
information from the senses is incorporated into mental activity in the form
of a memory.[31] Secondly, [storage](/wiki/Storage_\(memory\) "Storage
\(memory\)") involves taking this information and holding it indefinitely in
memory.[31] Lastly, retrieval is the ability to recall information from the
long-term memory storage. Each of these processes can be affected by
alcohol.[31]

[![Hippocampus.gif](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Hippocampus.gif/220px-
Hippocampus.gif)](/wiki/File:Hippocampus.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Hippocampus.gif "Enlarge")

Animation: Hippocampus (red)

### Explicit
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Explicit memory")]

**[Explicit memory](/wiki/Explicit_memory "Explicit memory")** requires
conscious and intentional effort for recall.[31] It includes both [episodic
memory](/wiki/Episodic_memory "Episodic memory") (for specific events, such as
a party) and [semantic memory](/wiki/Semantic_memory "Semantic memory") (for
general information, such as one's name).[31]

Alcohol impairs episodic encoding, specifically for cued recall, recognition
of completed word fragments, and free recall.[32] A
[blackout](/wiki/Blackout_\(alcohol-related_amnesia\) "Blackout \(alcohol-
related amnesia\)") is an example of a difficulty in [encoding](/wiki/Encoding
"Encoding") episodic memories due to [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol "Alcohol").
Blackouts are caused by a rapid increase in [blood alcohol
concentration](/wiki/Blood_alcohol_concentration "Blood alcohol
concentration") (BAC) which in turn distorts the neurons in the
[hippocampus](/wiki/Hippocampus "Hippocampus").[33] This distortion impairs a
person's ability to form new episodic memories.[33]

High doses of [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol "Alcohol") severely disrupt the storage
process of semantic memories.[34] [Alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol "Alcohol") was found
to impair the storage of novel stimuli but not that of previously learned
information.[34] Since alcohol affects the [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system"), it hinders
semantic storage functioning by restricting the consolidation of the
information from encoding.[34]

Retrieval of [explicit memory](/wiki/Explicit_memory "Explicit memory") is
significantly impaired by [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol "Alcohol"). When compared to
sober participants, intoxicated participants performed quite poorly on a
recall task for everyday events (episodic memory).[35] Intoxicated
participants are also slower to respond in reaction time tasks.[36] Alcohol
also impairs retrieval in word recognition tasks.[32] When both encoding and
retrieval take place during intoxication, there are surprisingly more
impairments for cued recall than for free recall.[32] In terms of gender
differences in retrieval processes, females tend to score lower than males on
recall tasks when intoxicated.[36]

### Implicit
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Implicit memory")]

**[Implicit memory](/wiki/Implicit_memory "Implicit memory")** does not
require conscious effort or intention for recall.[31] It occurs when previous
experience influences performance on a certain task.[31] This is evident in
[priming](/wiki/Priming_\(psychology\) "Priming \(psychology\)") experiments.
[Implicit memory](/wiki/Implicit_memory "Implicit memory") includes
[procedural memory](/wiki/Procedural_memory "Procedural memory"), which
influences our everyday behaviours, such as riding a bike or tying shoes.[31]
People can perform these abilities without thinking about them, which means
[procedural memory](/wiki/Procedural_memory "Procedural memory") functions
automatically. While retrieval of [explicit memory](/wiki/Explicit_memory
"Explicit memory") is severely impaired by alcohol, retrieval of [implicit
memory](/wiki/Implicit_memory "Implicit memory") is not.[35] Intoxicated
subjects score higher on recognition tasks (involving [implicit
memory](/wiki/Implicit_memory "Implicit memory")) than on recall tasks
(involving [explicit memory](/wiki/Explicit_memory "Explicit memory")).[35]

## Short-term
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Short-term memory")]

[Short-term memory](/wiki/Short-term_memory "Short-term memory") refers to
temporary storage of small amounts of information over short delays.[31]
[Digit span](/wiki/Digit_span "Digit span") refers to the proposed number of
pieces of information (5-9) that can be held in short-term memory. This is
also referred to as the magic number seven – plus or minus two. Any more
pieces of information than this, and newer items replace previous items.[37]
[Alcohol intoxication](/wiki/Alcohol_intoxication "Alcohol intoxication") has
been found to have dissociative effects on short-term memory and cognitive
functioning.[38][39]

[![Gray727_anterior_cingulate_cortex.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Gray727_anterior_cingulate_cortex.png/220px-
Gray727_anterior_cingulate_cortex.png)](/wiki/File:Gray727_anterior_cingulate_cortex.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray727_anterior_cingulate_cortex.png "Enlarge")

Anterior Cingulate Cortex (yellow)

[![Parietal_lobe_animation_small.gif](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/32/Parietal_lobe_animation_small.gif)](/wiki/File:Parietal_lobe_animation_small.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Parietal_lobe_animation_small.gif "Enlarge")

Animation: Parietal Lobe (red)

### Brain areas affected by
alcohol[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Brain areas affected by alcohol")]

Alcohol affects brain functioning. [Neurochemical](/wiki/Neurochemical
"Neurochemical") changes occurring in the [anterior
cingulate](/wiki/Anterior_cingulate "Anterior cingulate") are correlated with
altered short-term memory functions in the brains of young
[alcoholic](/wiki/Alcoholic "Alcoholic") men.[40] [fMRIs](/wiki/FMRI "FMRI")
of alcohol-dependent women displayed significantly less blood oxygen in the
frontal and parietal regions, especially in the right hemisphere.[41] This is
supported by findings of short-term memory impairment by lesions of the
[parietal lobe](/wiki/Parietal_lobe "Parietal lobe")[42] and prefrontal
cortex.[43] Associations between [Third ventricle](/wiki/Third_ventricle
"Third ventricle") volume and cognitive performance on memory tests have been
found in alcoholics.[44] Specifically, increases in third ventricular volume
correlate with a decline in memory performance.[44]

### Tasks and intoxication
findings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Tasks and intoxication findings")]

Short-term memory is commonly tested with visual tasks. Short-term memory,
especially for non-verbal and spatial material, are impaired by
intoxication.[44] Alcohol decreases [iconic memory](/wiki/Iconic_memory
"Iconic memory") (a type of visual short-term memory).[45] With BACs between
80–84 mg/dl, more intrusion errors occur in a delayed recall task compared to
a control group.[46] Intrusion errors, which represent reflective cognitive
functioning, occur when irrelevant information is produced. Alcoholics have
less control of inhibiting intrusions.[46] Acute alcohol intoxication in
social drinkers caused more intrusion errors in delayed recall tasks than in
immediate free recall tasks.[46] Acute alcohol intoxication increases
susceptibility to interference, which allows for more intrusion errors when
there is a short delay.[46] [Free recall](/wiki/Free_recall "Free recall")
(given list of words then asked to recall list) is significantly lower and
therefore impaired by alcohol intoxication.[47][48] [Encoding](/wiki/Encoding
"Encoding") deficits were found in verbal free recall and recognition tasks
under the influence of alcohol.[49] A discrimination task found significant
alcohol-related impairments in [depth perception](/wiki/Depth_perception
"Depth perception") and in [visual short-term memory](/wiki/Visual_short-
term_memory "Visual short-term memory").[50] [State-dependent
learning](/wiki/State-dependent_learning "State-dependent learning") and
relearning studies in male heavy drinkers demonstrate that the condition of
intoxication while learning and sobriety when tested caused a performance
deficit in free recall tasks.[51] These findings are supportive of alcohol-
induced storage deficits (not retrieval deficits).[51] The effects of acute
alcohol consumption on visual short-term memory, stereoscopic depth
perception, and attention were studied. A 33% alcohol condition showed
significant impairments in depth perception and in visual short-term memory
(assessed by the vernier discrimination task).[52]

[![Working_memory_model.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Working_memory_model.svg/220px-
Working_memory_model.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Working_memory_model.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Working_memory_model.svg "Enlarge")

Working Memory Model. Alcohol intoxication can disrupt rehearsal strategies
which may involve the phonological loop and/or the visuospatial sketchpad.

## Effects on working
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Effects on working memory")]

[Working memory](/wiki/Working_memory "Working memory") allows one to keep
things in mind while simultaneously performing complex tasks.[31] It involves
a system for the temporary storage and manipulation of information, forming a
crucial link between perception and controlled action.[53] Evidence suggests
that working memory involves three components: the _[central
executive](/wiki/Central_executive "Central executive")_ which controls
attention, the _visuo-spatial sketchpad_ which holds and manipulates spatial
information, and the _phonological loop_ which performs a similar function for
auditory and speech-based information.[53]

### In the short
term[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: In the short term")]

Alcohol consumption has substantial, measurable effects on working memory,
though these effects vary greatly between individual responses. Little is
known about the neural mechanisms that underlie these individual
differences.[54] It is also found that alcohol impairs working memory by
affecting mnemonic strategies and executive processes rather than by shrinking
the basic holding capacity of working memory. Isolated acute-moderate levels
of alcohol intoxication do not profoundly physically alter the structures
which are critical for working memory function, such as the [frontal
cortex](/wiki/Frontal_cortex "Frontal cortex"), [parietal
cortex](/wiki/Parietal_cortex "Parietal cortex"), [anterior
cingulate](/wiki/Anterior_cingulate "Anterior cingulate"), and parts of the
[basal ganglia](/wiki/Basal_ganglia "Basal ganglia").[38] One finding
regarding the effects of alcohol on working memory points out that alcohol
reduces working memory only in individuals with a high baseline working memory
capacity,[55] which suggests that alcohol might not uniformly affect working
memory in different individuals. Alcohol appears to impair the capacity of
working memory to modulate response inhibition.[55] Alcohol disinhibits
behaviour, but only in individuals with a low baseline working memory
capacity.[55] An interesting finding is that incentive to perform well with
working memory measurement tasks while under the influence of alcohol '_does_
in fact have some effect on working memory, in that it boosts scores in rate
of mental scanning and reaction time to stimulus, but did not reduce number of
errors compared to subjects with no incentive to perform well.[56] Even acute
alcohol intoxication (a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08-0.09%) produces a
substantial impairment of working memory processes that require mnemonic
rehearsal strategies.[38] Alcohol is less likely to impair a working memory
task that does not rely on [memory rehearsal](/wiki/Memory_rehearsal "Memory
rehearsal") or associated mnemonic strategies.[38] Because of this, working
memory is very susceptible to falter when a person is participating in tasks
involving retention concerning auditory and visual sequences.[38] A real world
and interesting example of this is failure of guitarists or other musicians
performing concerts to cue in on auditory patterns and make it known that
their performance is hindered by intoxication, whereas professional basketball
(a less sequence-heavy activity for working memory) standout [Ron
Artest](/wiki/Ron_Artest "Ron Artest") recently admitted in an interview with
_[Sporting News](/wiki/Sporting_News "Sporting News")_ to drinking heavily
during half-time in the early days of his career and it having little if any
recognizable effect on his working memory. His former coach Fran Fraschilla
has gone on record saying:[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

> "It's a surprise because every day at practice, he came out in a mood to
> play. He came out in a basketball rage. He was fully committed; he wanted to
> let our upperclassmen know that he was the alpha male. It never came up that
> he had any sort of a problem with alcohol. This is the first I've heard of
> it."

### In the long
term[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: In the long term")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png) | This article **needs more[medical references](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_\(medicine\) "Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources \(medicine\)") for [verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability") or relies too heavily on primary sources, specifically: primary sources should be replaced; consider using [PMID](/wiki/PubMed_Identifier "PubMed Identifier") [23905882](//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23905882) and [PMID](/wiki/PubMed_Identifier "PubMed Identifier") [28470828](//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28470828)**. Please review the contents of the article and [add the appropriate references](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit) if you can. Unsourced or poorly sourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(July 2017)_ |  [![Rod of Asclepius2.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Rod_of_Asclepius2.svg/12px-Rod_of_Asclepius2.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Rod_of_Asclepius2.svg)  
---|---|---  
  
Alcohol has shown to have _some_ long-term effect on working memory. Findings
have shown that for working memory to be substantially affected, long-term,
heavy drinking must be sustained over a long period of time as up to one drink
per day does not impair cognitive function and may actually decrease the risk
of cognitive decline.[57] Furthermore, chronic [alcoholism](/wiki/Alcoholism
"Alcoholism") is associated with impairment in sustained attention and visual
working memory. Thus, alcoholics have reduced ability, but not necessarily
_inability_ , to perform these executive tasks, assumed to be subserved by
regions of [prefrontal cortex](/wiki/Prefrontal_cortex "Prefrontal
cortex").[58] While it may not serve as a surprise that chronic alcoholism has
been linked to decreased cognitive function including working memory, one
surprising finding is not only that even moderate levels of alcohol
consumption during pregnancy were shown to have an adverse effect on the
child's working memory when tested at 7.5 years of age, but that working
memory may be the most important aspect of attention that is adversely
affected by prenatal alcohol exposure.[59]

## Prospective
memory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Prospective memory")]

_[Prospective memory](/wiki/Prospective_memory "Prospective memory")_ involves
remembering to carry out an intended action in the future without an explicit
reminder.[31] Alcohol has been found to impair this ability. Chronic heavy
alcohol users report significantly more prospective forgetting compared to
low-dose and alcohol-free controls.[60] The Prospective Memory Questionnaire
assesses short-term habitual prospective memory, long-term episodic
prospective memory, and internally cued prospective memory.[60] Chronic heavy
alcohol users reported significantly greater deficits for all three aspects of
prospective memory.[60] Individuals that report heavy alcohol use report 24%
more difficulties with prospective memory than those who report that they are
light drinkers and 30% more difficulties than those who report that they never
drink.[61] The effects of alcohol on prospective memory can also be assessed
in the laboratory by simulating prospective memory tasks that individuals face
in everyday life. Individuals who are given 0.6 g/kg alcohol prior to
performing prospective memory tasks do significantly poorer than a
[placebo](/wiki/Placebo "Placebo") group.[62] Alcohol can damage the
prefrontal and frontal areas of the brain, and this may be responsible for
prospective memory impairments since prospective memory performance is highly
correlated with frontal executive functions.[60]

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Effects_of_alcohol_on_memory&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

The memory inhibiting effects of alcohol are often a prominent topic in
popular culture. It appears in movies, books, and television shows. Several
movies show characters drinking alcohol to the point of memory loss and
awakening the next morning with a host of problems due to actions they
performed while intoxicated.

One example is _The Hangover_ , where three groomsmen lose the groom during a
bachelor party in Las Vegas, so they retrace their steps to find him.[63] The
characters still had functioning implicit/procedural memory, which allowed
them to carry out the many acts they performed that night, but their episodic
memory was impaired and thus they had no recollection of the events occurring.
In addition to alcohol the characters were also under the influence of
[flunitrazepam](/wiki/Flunitrazepam "Flunitrazepam").

Another movie is _What Happens in Vegas_. After an intoxicated night in "Sin
City," two people wake-up to find they got married.[64]

Songs such as _Waking Up in Vegas_ by [Katy Perry](/wiki/Katy_Perry "Katy
Perry")[65] and _Last Name_ by [Carrie Underwood](/wiki/Carrie_Underwood
"Carrie Underwood")[66] also depict characters waking up and not remembering
the night before due to alcohol consumption.

By some accounts, popular culture makes light of the memory problems that can
result from alcohol consumption.

The court case [R. v. Daviault](/wiki/R._v._Daviault "R. v. Daviault") [1994]
concerned the viability of a legal defense based on intoxication.

Law and Order: Special Victims Unit; in season 11 episode 4, Hammered, a
recovering alcoholic was coersed to drink by a business partner and later
wakes up to a dead woman in his bed.

qa.question: what part of the brain is memory affected by alcohol

nq_2150_10.Query Analysis: The query asks about the specific part of the brain that is affected by alcohol in terms of memory.
nq_2150_10.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the hippocampus is the part of the brain affected by alcohol in terms of memory.
nq_2150_10.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the effects of alcohol on different types of memory, including episodic and semantic memory. It explains how alcohol impairs episodic encoding and the storage process of semantic memories. It specifically mentions that blackouts, caused by a rapid increase in blood alcohol concentration, distort neurons in the hippocampus, impairing the formation of new episodic memories.
nq_2150_10.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document includes the keywords 'memory', 'alcohol', and 'hippocampus'.
nq_2150_10.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document explicitly mentions 'hippocampus', which is the part of the brain affected by alcohol as per the answer.
nq_2150_10.Key Information Matching: The document directly discusses how alcohol affects the hippocampus, which is the key information required by the query.
nq_2150_10.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly answers the query by mentioning the hippocampus as the part of the brain affected by alcohol.
nq_2150_10.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides detailed information on how alcohol affects memory processes, including the role of the hippocampus.
nq_2150_10.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it explicitly mentions the hippocampus and explains how alcohol affects this part of the brain in relation to memory. It provides substantial useful context and directly answers the query.
